I looked out our second-floor window and everyone was out riding their bikes, wearing shorts and sundresses – families picnicking around Lake Merritt. I stood there numb to everything.

Now, what? What about that loft we were going to get? Or the two children we imagined running in our backyard?

Snapping out of my daze, I heard his voice shouting from downstairs, “Grab my bike off the mantle, will you?” The studio now looked like it did the day we arrived. Empty. Sunlight hit the wooden floors, and I closed the door before slipping the keys under. The smell of the panadería across the street whiffed into my nose as I took one more glance at the old man who waited to die on our street every day, smoking his last cigarette while notes of jazz filled the city. All of this ultimately became a part of me.

But this isn’t our story; it’s mine, and you’re just a part of it.

I hauled everything I owned into my car, with my ex-lover’s bicycle attached to the roof. The fog eventually disappeared, the roads shifted from pavement to gravel and the heat seeped into my skin. Mountains on every corner replaced buildings, and we were back on 1-10 headed for the desert. The only noise you could hear was the clamoring of the wine glasses we bought together, the rattling of his bike and a loud, vast, open sound only the desert landscape can produce. Two summers ago, after a stint of city living and what seemed to be an enormous amount of young love, I found myself back at my childhood address. Seeing the windmills silhouetted against the mountainside, the comfort of home rushed into my body. The desert held a familiar scent – my grandmother’s Filipino cooking, soy sauce mixed in with vinegar, ginger and garlic simmering ever so slowly in a huge metal pot, along with the subtle smell of coconut bundled in banana leaves – and the feeling that everything was going to be alright. Or at least that was the sensation I craved.

There I was, unpacking everything in my parents’ garage. I’d left behind one of the best teaching jobs in Oakland and a life I thought I knew. On the evening of my return to the desert, the gradient of colors from the sunset melded into a fiery warmth that embraced my existence. Within that moment, I realized I needed to let all of it happen.

Exhausted from the drive, I went to the backyard and dug my feet into the earth. The damp grass felt good against my hot skin, and I wasn’t sure how to move forward or if I even could. As I looked up at the summer moon, my body knew this was the end of a relationship but the beginning of something new. Sometimes people, places and things happen because they help you arrive at your next destination. I never planned to move back here, but the desert chose me.

Michelle Castillo is a writer, educator, community arts organizer and social activist based out of Palm Springs. She is currently an MFA candidate for poetry at the University of California, Riverside-Palm Desert and is at work on her first poetry collection. She has lived in several cities but will always call the desert home. You can find her online at mothereartherdiaries.wordpress.com.

Holding my hands in front of an exhaust pipe. While the car is on. It’s 4:30 a.m. and I’m wondering if the McDonald’s in Baker is open 24 hours. I’m wondering if I’m up for whoever would be at a McDonald’s in Baker in 5 a.m. I’m gauging the drive to Tecopa and imagining, over and over, sinking into the hot mud of the spring. I lift my head into the cold air, hands still rubbing each other in the exhaust, and see the first light hit the white cross and then bleed out on the pink rocks. Mojave Desert Preserve, January.

My 9-year-old daughter scratches the ice on the inside of the SUV window, thrusting her hand out of the mass of her sleeping bag wrestled into a sitting position. Heart, she scratches. Smiley face. And then the dog’s name. We’re up.

In the next hour, she’ll watch the local college field trip cool older kids at White Cross Campground get up from their dozen tents and start packing for their day’s trek. She’ll get growled at by the dude in the remote back of the dispersed camping area who wants us to stay further than 200 yards from his motorhome. She’ll scramble through scree to find petroglyphs peeking through chia flowers. Until we are parked and drinking hot tea made on a burner in the back of the truck while the trains rush by, the conductor blasting the horn at her, at us, the only humans standing within a few miles, waving back at him, as he shoots past and sinks back into the desert.

Later, after the dog barks at being left standing on the lava rocks as we crawl into a cave, after we carry the dog down the ladder into the lava tubes, stand in the cave a bit, and carry the fool dog back up, a guy says to her, watching the entire circus enterprise, “You should know, you have a really cool mom.” But I want to tell him, oh tell her anything at this age, she also thinks I’m a good singer and God knows that’s not true. But she also knows I just tossed her a cup in the back of the car and said pee here then. She knows there comes a moment in every night in every tent where I say enough, please stop talking. She is just now getting old enough to know all moms are not like me. If I get the balance just right, somewhere between tough love and gentle listener, that may in the end be said to be to my credit.

In the meantime, January in the cold desert still sounds good to her, so I haven’t broken her yet.

Living in the far southeastern end of the Coachella Valley was not always something I appreciated. Definitely not when I was a younger person. Growing up on the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Indian Reservation in Thermal, the desolateness seemed to stunt my ability to dream. The vast open desert, agricultural fields and treacherous-looking mountains represented infinite emptiness at the time. I remember feeling so far away from anywhere, and believing that everything was happening someplace else.

In high school, my parents facilitated an interdistrict transfer for me to Palm Desert High. They believed I would receive a better education there. It was a different world from the community of Torres Martinez. Some of my fellow students had cars at ages 16 and 17 that were more fancy and expensive than those of our teachers. Life seemed privileged for a lot of my peers. But not for me and not for the young people I knew growing up. Our reservation and the surrounding rural community was, as it still remains, a place where many who live there work the hardest and also earn the least.

Experiencing this proximity of poverty to extreme wealth in the desert was suffocating to me. Thus, as a teen, I could not wait to leave. Fortunately, my university education led me to schools in South Dakota, Humboldt County in Northern California and the Bay Area. All places of tremendous beauty. America’s vast great plains. The regal redwood forest. The state’s largest estuary. These journeys had the same origin and led me back to the same place, Torres Martinez. Each voyage away from home strengthened my appreciation for the reservation landscape. The distance from the rushing nature of city life now fosters my ability to think clearly.

People often come to our area and see nothing but poverty and potential for expansion. But the reality is that Desert Cahuilla history, lifeways and culture have been there far longer than anything else. Those of us who were taught to can see the places relevant to our creation all around us. Everything, down to the natural colors of the earth, has meaning to us.

It’s clear that not everyone sees it this way. To some, our home area is a place where they can leave things they don’t want near them. Unwanted human waste, polluted water, old furniture and useless appliances are dumped in our homelands. Developers don’t see the wide open space as a sanctuary for free desert animals and plants to live, like my family does. Though the tribe has authority on what happens within our boundaries, there’s no regulating everything. Our quiet is encroached on weekends with the sound of bullets ringing out from sport hunters who are after the birds, as well as the incessant hum of cars from the nearby racetrack.

The proximity that once drove me away is coming even closer to my home. But now, it’s what keeps me around appreciating all that remains.

Terria Smith is a tribal member of the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Indians. She is the editor of News from Native California, a quarterly magazine “devoted to the vibrant cultures, art, languages, histories, social justice movements, and stories of California’s diverse Indian peoples.” She is an undergraduate alum of Humboldt State University and has a master’s degree from the University of California Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism.

search_result.title: Border wall construction in Arizona causes environmental concerns
search_result.text:
HEREFORD, Ariz. — A scrappy wind tugs at the branches of cottonwood trees above the San Pedro River near the border in southeastern Arizona. The fickle gusts ripple, then smooth the surface of the ankle-deep water that has been sustained by a wet winter. The cottonwoods creak amid the steady flow of the river, a dulcet tone in the desert.

Where the river crosses the international border, the water passes between metal Normandy-style barriers, X-shaped metal barricades arranged on either side of the channel, connected by a horizontal steel bar that blocks vehicles from driving through the riverbed.

Pink ribbons tied around a dozen cottonwoods closest to the border flap in the breeze. Small wood posts inscribed with the words “remove trees” are placed in front of them.

The trees are marked for removal as part of President Donald Trump’s attempt to fulfill his campaign promise to build a wall along the southern border.

As construction moves forward in this rugged corner of conservative Cochise County, long-cultivated relationships among local ranchers, environmental groups and Border Patrol agents have begun to unravel, the mistrust fed by a lack of communication and reliable information. Agencies that worked together a decade ago are now on shaky ground.

Many people are concerned that wildlife migration, sensitive habitats, undeveloped landscapes and limited water resources will be irreparably harmed because the government has waived dozens of federal environmental and cultural protection laws that would typically trigger thorough studies before construction took place.

On Friday, four conservation groups asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review lower court decisions that allowed the Trump administration to waive the environmental laws.

In Arizona, much of the construction is occurring on federal, rather than privately owned, lands, eliminating obstacles to the building process like purchasing land from private stakeholders or going through the eminent domain process.

The U.S. government controls a 60-foot-wide strip of land on the border that spans California, Arizona and New Mexico from the Pacific Ocean to where the Rio Grande becomes the international boundary. Known as the Roosevelt Reservation, the easement was established in 1907 by President Theodore Roosevelt to keep the border "free from obstruction as a protection against the smuggling of goods” between the United States and Mexico, according to the original proclamation.

The Roosevelt easement runs along multiple protected areas across Arizona, including Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, which is part of the traditional homelands of the Tohono O’odham Nation.

In far southeast Arizona, the easement hems the San Pedro Riparian National Conservation Area and the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, two of the most biodiverse and rare desert water systems in the Southwest. That leaves these areas in the crosshairs of a fast-tracked construction process.

In May, the federal government awarded a $646 million contract to Southwest Valley Constructors, a subsidiary of Omaha-based Kiewit Corporation, to replace approximately 63 miles of existing vehicle and pedestrian barriers along the border in Pima and Cochise counties.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the agency that oversees border security, proposed replacing about 43 miles of such barriers in Pima County and about 19 miles in Cochise County — including the approximately 0.3 miles of Normandy-style barrier that currently cuts through the San Pedro at the border — with 18- to 30-foot, concrete-filled steel bollards.

“Bollard-style” fencing consists of steel posts spaced several inches apart, close enough together that the narrow openings could become clogged with debris from flowing water, effectively damming a river or wash. The proposal also described improving or constructing new roads, installing lights, and “other detection technology.”

Just weeks after U.S. Rep. Raúl Grijalva sent a letter to the Department of Homeland Security, which oversees Customs and Border Protection, expressing concern about the lack of consultation with the Tohono O'odham nation, the contractor cleared the easement near Quitobaquito Springs, an important water resource in the area and sacred site to the Hia-Ced and Tohono O'odham.

“They could break ground here tomorrow and nobody would know,” said Laiken Jordahl, borderlands campaigner for Tucson-based conservation group the Center for Biological Diversity, as he observed the marked cottonwood trees by the San Pedro recently.

“It's such a shame that all this would be done with no inclusion of the public, no engagement of stakeholders, no assessment of how this could change the ecology of the river," Jordahl said. "It’s our tax dollars being used and none of us have consented to this.”

When a river meets a wall

Of the former great Southwestern rivers, the San Pedro remains free-flowing and undammed.

The river begins just south of the border in Sonora, Mexico, then winds north into Arizona, a rare remnant of what was once a vast network of similar river systems throughout the Southwest that disappeared as a result of damming, drought and human use over the past several hundred years. The river snakes about 140 miles from its headwaters in Mexico to the Gila River, a green artery in a dry landscape.

On either side of the river corridor, fencing designed to prevent both vehicles and pedestrians from crossing into Arizona currently stretches about 40 miles between the Coronado National Memorial to the west and the border town of Douglas to the east.

The fencing on this stretch of border is made up of varying iterations of pedestrian blockades that have been installed over the decades, from 18-foot bollard-style barriers spanning several miles on each side of the river to shorter fencing made of a variety of metal designs.

The fencing between Coronado National Memorial and Douglas is broken only at the 0.3 miles of Normandy-style vehicle barrier across the San Pedro. Border Patrol agents are stationed at the river 24 hours a day.

In an emailed statement to The Arizona Republic on Jan. 16, Customs and Border Protection wrote that the agency will conduct hydraulic and hydrological analyses “to ensure the new barrier does not deflect water or obstruct flow” at the San Pedro. The statement described possible barrier designs such as “gates or grates to allow for the passage of flood waters and debris.”

If the proposed 30-foot metal posts are constructed at the river here, even with some floodgates, conservation groups, locals and agencies worry the river will effectively be dammed.

On Jan. 26, more than a thousand protesters, primarily locals, filled the Hereford bridge across the San Pedro River to protest the construction. They echoed many of the concerns that longtime activists and community leaders have voiced in recent years.

“This place is so special,” said Tricia Gerrodette, a local who has fought to protect the San Pedro for more than 24 years. “There's nothing else like this in the Southwest. And we keep chipping away at it.”

In 2007, when the government proposed a similar bollard-style fence across the river, the Bureau of Land Management wrote in a memo to DHS: "Regardless of the maintenance commitments by Border Patrol, the proposed fence could inadvertently act as a flood control structure altering natural flood characteristics."

During the summer monsoon, the river swells, and debris, trees, trash and other objects would likely pile up against the fence, these groups say. Just a few weeks ago, debris and mud could be seen pushed up against some of the Normandy barriers in the floodplain. Currently, the Border Patrol removes these barriers during the monsoon to prevent flooding and debris buildup.

"These floods are critical to the health of the river," Jordahl said. "If you put in structures that essentially dam it, you're really altering the ecosystem that we see here. This is already an extremely strained resource, and to wall it off and essentially dam it is just insult to injury."

When the design plans are finalized, they will be implemented without the environmental and cultural studies usually required by federal law for construction projects.

The Trump administration has waived dozens of laws to expedite construction of the wall across Arizona and other border states. The controversial action was made possible in 2005, when Congress granted then-President George W. Bush the authority to bypass federal environmental and cultural protection laws to speed up border wall construction on the California-Mexico border. Because the waiver authority wasn’t limited to that specific time and place, the Trump administration has used it to accelerate the current border wall construction.

In a petition on Friday to the U.S. Supreme Court, four conservation groups argued that the waivers were unconstitutional and threatened natural resources along the border.

“The Trump administration has turned our safe and beautiful borderlands and border communities into a place where our nation’s most important laws — the laws that protect the environment and ensure the health, safety and well-being of communities everywhere else in America — literally do not apply,” Kevin Bixby, executive director of the Southwest Environmental Center, said in a press release.

The 1970 National Environmental Policy Act, or NEPA, which is one of the 40-plus laws that have been waived, would require environmental analyses and impact statements prior to construction. The law would ensure that environmental concerns such as how bollard-style fencing might impact wildlife migration and the floodplain would be considered equally alongside other factors, such as the effectiveness of bollard fencing in the San Pedro in preventing illegal smuggling or border crossings.

Customs and Border Protection says that despite the waivers, it remains "committed to responsible environmental stewardship and meeting the intent of these laws to the greatest extent possible while allowing the Government to meet its requirements to secure the southern border," the agency wrote in an email.

The agency spokesperson went on to write that they are "actively engaged" with the federal agencies that manage protected areas to identify wildlife passages and "other design elements that support wildlife migration without compromising border security."

Since the construction was announced in May, neither the Bureau of Land Management nor the Fish and Wildlife Service has received information about specific border wall design plans for the San Pedro River or the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, managed by each respectively. Customs and Border Protection told The Republic in an email that the contractor was expected to finalize designs by the end of this month, but designs remain under consideration.

Despite border security officials' assurances that the contractor is working closely to address environmental concerns with the agencies that oversee protected areas throughout the borderlands, the communication has been inadequate, officials and environmental groups say.

"Any of the public lands that are being potentially impacted by this, we're not receiving information on what's happening or what's going to happen, so it's really hard to respond in any way other than just monitor what's happening," said an agency official who was given anonymity because agencies overseeing protected areas impacted by construction have been directed not to speak with the media about the border wall construction without referring them to appropriate public information officers.

“NEPA is not a law that stops projects, it's a law that requires people to talk about the best ways to do things to minimize impacts and achieve success,” the official said. “When that is wiped away, both of those objectives are pretty hard to meet.”

HANGING IN THE BALANCE: Groundwater drilling could affect fragile springs

A fragile place: The Sky Islands region

Some 35 miles east from the San Pedro crossing into Arizona is the town of Douglas, “the premier southwestern border community” as it calls itself on its water tower.

Arizona and Sonora license plates are seen on the roads. Outside of town, the bollard-style border wall, built by the Bush administration during the mid-2000s, turns to vehicle barriers. Where the paved road turns to gravel, then dirt, structures that look like cell towers become visible. They are Border Patrol watchtowers, equipped with cameras so strong they can capture license plates on Mexico’s Highway 2 several miles away.

On the unpaved Geronimo Trail, named for the Apache leader who surrendered to U.S. troops nearby in the late 1800s, the wind breaks the quiet in bursts and whips, and only a sharp eye can see the line across the sloping valley that designates where Mexico ends and the United States begins. The land is open and vast. To the east, the Peloncillo Mountains rise up out of the desert, and the snow-dusted Chiricahua Mountains peer out from the north.

An 18-wheeler barrels down the road and another truck follows, spraying water for dust control. On this remote road, new signs have been erected every few yards with slogans like “Don’t let your journey end on a gurney” or “Safety is a way of life” to encourage construction workers to drive with caution.

The road climbs a small hill, and in the near distance, a few miles of new 30-foot bollard-style border fencing looks like a black snake crawling across the landscape, the upper reaches creating an unnaturally smooth line against the horizon.

The beeping and bustle of construction noise seems out of place. Big rig trucks circle a concrete-making facility, churning water and rocks. Beside it, a dirt lot has been cleared for parking. A large truck parks under a yellow tank to refill with several thousand gallons of water, while the sun peeks through the clouds and the shadows shift across the valley and mountains beyond.

Just a mile or so beyond is the historic John Slaughter Ranch Museum, where former Cochise County Sheriff “Texas John” Slaughter made his life in the late 1800s.

The ranch is next to the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, a 2,369-acre marsh that is all that remains of the once permanently flowing creeks, springs and wetlands, or cienegas, that stretched across the sacaton grasslands that characterized the San Bernardino Valley in Slaughter’s time and long before.

Today, about two-thirds of the wetlands are in the Mexican state of Sonora. For centuries, the cienega was a sanctuary for humans and wildlife.

For centuries, too, this region has been under stress. As settlement in the region expanded in the late 19th century, farming, mining and livestock production competed for the same water. The valley sits on a vast aquifer, water that is likely as ancient as the Pleistocene, that feeds springs connected by volcanic tubes underground. It’s part of the Rio Yaqui River basin, the largest river in northwest Mexico.

Over time, increased pressure from growing populations and cattle grazing on both sides of the border led to local extinctions of many species, and soon the wetlands were largely converted to individual ponds and artesian wells. Mesquite and thornscrub carpeted the valley instead of native grass.

In 1982, the remaining wetland was designated a refuge to protect native fish species that were on the verge of going extinct. Private landowners, conservation organizations and government agencies from the U.S. and Mexico decided to work together to maintain the “delicate balance that has been in place for centuries, providing quality habitat for fish, wildlife, and people dependent on the Rio Yaqui Basin,” the Fish and Wildlife Service writes in its brochure for the area.

The new border wall fencing is planned to be built across 19 miles in this area, which is about 14 miles east of Douglas. It will abut the 2.6 miles of the refuge along the border, as well as the Slaughter Ranch.

Fred and Vickie Dunn have managed the Slaughter Ranch for the past five years. Fred is a former cattle rancher and stuntman, and Vickie is an author. They laugh easily together and finish each other’s sentences, or Vickie finishes Fred’s before he says something he may regret. Now, instead of asking about the history of the ranch, tourists often ask them about the wall.

“People either want to gripe about it or praise it,” Vickie said. “Border security is important for every country, but the wall is not going to be a solution to our problems. We have the virtual wall with the towers in the area and Border Patrol does an excellent job. Building a physical wall here is possibly going to be detrimental on many levels.”

“It’s a conversation point up north and then they get here and they see it,” Fred said. "I'll talk about the ranch, I'll talk about the wildlife, but I don't want to talk about the metal fence. I'm tired of looking at it."

The biggest concern is water. The Slaughter Ranch, until recently, has relied on artesian wells (wells that don’t require pumping because water comes to the surface of the ground by way of springs) for water. They worry that the water being pumped for construction may tap their pond dry, or worse. If the aquifer is drained, the area could become a sinkhole, they said a hydrologist told them.

Customs and Border Protection said in a Feb. 5 email to The Republic that the contractor is currently pumping approximately 180,000 gallons of water per day for this section of the project.

“The information coming in is sporadic," Fred said. "The panic over the water, the panic over the construction, the whole thing. We could wake up tomorrow morning with the pond going down like a toilet bowl and the house halfway to hell.”

“We’re all on the same aquifer,” Vickie added. “They said if they drain us for our personal use we can get water from their well. But if they drain the aquifer, it doesn’t matter. We’re not gonna have it, they’re not gonna have it, nobody’s gonna have it.”

The Dunns recently drilled a 480-foot well to pump water for domestic use in case the border wall construction causes their pond to run dry.

“The whole reason we spent the money for that well was if something happened, if the horror stories came true, we would hopefully be able to maintain domestic water, so at least we can keep basic livestock and us getting water,” Fred said. “We've already forfeited the grass.”

Customs and Border Protection is currently using five wells in the areas east of Douglas for border wall construction, including existing wells on privately owned properties near the refuge and Slaughter Ranch.

A spokesperson for the agency wrote in an email to The Republic that they do not currently have plans to drill additional wells in or around the San Bernardino Wildlife Refuge.

WORKING TOGETHER: Looking for common ground on the San Pedro River

'An amazing part of the world'

Like the San Pedro, this tiny protected area, administered by the Fish and Wildlife Service, is a rare reliable water resource in the desert. Even if additional groundwater pumping doesn’t deplete the aquifer, the area is a vital migratory pathway for wide-ranging species like jaguars, mountain lions, wolves and black bears.

With climate change increasing the severity of droughts and transforming habitats in the Southwest, migration pathways are even more essential for wildlife survival. The jaguar will likely go extinct in the U.S. if 30-foot bollard-style fencing seals the border in this region, conservationists say.

EXTINCTION FEARS: A border wall could drive the jaguar extinct in America

Border protection officials told The Republic that the agency is "actively engaged" with the Fish and Wildlife Service "to identify small wildlife passages and other design elements within the planned border wall that support wildlife migration without compromising border security,” and that some designs could include small animal gates that can be open “during migration season.”

“It's the animals that you see every day out here, the deer, the javelina, the bobcats, the mountain lions, where I think we'll see a really dramatic effect on what's happening when those resources are fragmented,” said Myles Traphagen, borderlands program manager for the conservation group Wildlands Network.

“And, of course, that's going to have a reverse cascade on the larger predators like mountain lions and jaguars," Traphagen said. "It's not just all the big-ticket items, it’s the smaller ones that I think are going to have really large impacts.”

The San Pedro and the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge are in one of the most biodiverse regions of the world: the Sky Islands. The 57 isolated mountain “islands” are separated by desert and grassland “seas.”

In this region, the flora and fauna of the neotropical Sierra Madre Mountains come up from the south to meet the temperate north of the Colorado Plateau; the Chihuahan Desert stretches in from the east and the Sonoran Desert from the west.

“There's several places just south of here where you'll see pine trees, oaks and saguaros all in the same location,” said Traphagen. “Black bears are here as well as jaguars. This is an amazing part of the world.”

A 2011 study identified Sky Islands wildlife as at risk of experiencing some of the most detrimental impacts from the already existing border wall infrastructure in this area.

Fred Dunn has come across Mexican gray wolves and mountain lions and countless deer and javelina, animals with no knowledge of international boundaries that move back and forth across the border on a sometimes-daily basis. The wildlife is a big reason he and Vickie love their job managing the ranch.

“The way I look at it, we’re collateral damage,” Fred said of the water situation and the impact on wildlife corridors. “We can’t do a thing about the wall. But there’s gotta be some compromise here somewhere.”

A DIFFERENT BORDER STORY: Building a different kind of wall to revive a dying land

'It pushed the traffic out here'

Amid cries from environmentalists of "no moo in '92" and "cattle-free in '93," Bill McDonald gathered some of his fellow ranchers in the San Bernardino Valley for a talk.

The fifth-generation rancher, whose great-great-grandfather arrived in this harsh but beautiful landscape in 1907, was a forward-thinker who knew he had to find some common ground with environmentalists who wanted grazing off public lands, but he also knew ranching was a way of life he and his neighbors weren’t going to quit anytime soon.

“Everybody out here leases federal and state lands to graze on in addition to their private land. That's just the makeup of the state of Arizona and most of the Western states,” said McDonald, a towering man with a friendly voice.

What eventually resulted from that first meeting was a surprising coalition — environmental and conservation organizations, multigenerational rancher families and federal agencies — working together. They called themselves the Malpai Borderlands Group, named for the volcanic malapai rock common in the area, derived from the Spanish word "malpaís," or badlands, a term used by early Spanish explorers for the black landscapes of volcanic rock across the Southwest and Mexico.

The coalition remains a rare example of long-standing, strong partnerships between groups that often have conflicting interests.

“Our focus was on conservation and protecting open space and trying to prevent development, because that was the threat at the time, and also trying to keep ranching viable,” McDonald said. “The border came along later, much later.”

Drug smuggling from Mexico was a big problem in the region, primarily in developed areas like Douglas, which sits across the border from the larger Mexican city of Agua Prieta. In 1990, the first drug-smuggling tunnel was discovered between Agua Prieta and Douglas to funnel cocaine into the United States, authorities said at the time.

During those years, Douglas was considered a hot spot for drug and human trafficking, with illegal activity peaking in the late 1990s and early 2000s. In response, the federal government spent billions of dollars to build more border infrastructure where there were cities on both sides of the border, such as El Paso, San Diego and Nogales, as well as Douglas.

The new pedestrian fencing helped deter the foot traffic in town, but as a result, illegal activities were funneled to more remote areas of the borderlands, including the area of the San Bernardino Refuge and the San Pedro River corridor.

“Out here in the country, we weren’t getting any traffic,” McDonald said of the time. “The government decided to tighten up the border around the towns, and as it did, it pushed the traffic out here.”

After 9/11, an attempt to seal the border

Traphagen, the border conservation activist, started his career at the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, working for the Fish and Wildlife Service as a biologist in the late 1990s. He remembers that he would encounter small groups of migrants from all over the world in the refuge. Once, he came across a group of 18 Vietnamese men.

“They were coming looking for work. Mostly men, small groups of them,” Traphagen recalled.

There were drug smugglers too. Ranchers were subjected to vandalism and trash on their properties, as well as intimidation and threats from smugglers at times. Drug-smuggling vehicles cut new roads across the landscape.

The Malpai Group, concerned for both the degradation of the land and the safety of their communities, asked the Border Patrol to do more, to station more agents in the area and incorporate more surveillance technology.

“They really weren't paying much attention to us for a long time,” said McDonald. “There were a few more agents running around out here, but there wasn’t a concerted effort in my opinion to do anything about what was happening out here on the ranches.”

After the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration began a frenzied effort to seal the border. The administration created the Department of Homeland Security, and relocated the Border Patrol to its oversight instead of the Department of Justice. They started hiring more agents; the Tucson sector, which spans 262 miles along the Arizona border, had employed about 1,500 agents before 9/11. Now, there are about 3,600.

In 2006, as part of the border security efforts, the Bush administration attempted to do almost exactly what the Trump administration is doing now. In 2008, the Department of Homeland Security invoked its Congress-mandated right to waive 37-plus environmental laws to expedite border wall construction, primarily new bollard-style fencing, along 700 miles of the border, including through the San Pedro River and the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge.

“Without question, this action taken on behalf of DHS will be a new paradigm for all involved,” a Fish and Wildlife officer wrote in an email to his colleagues at the time, according to documents obtained by the Sierra Club through a Freedom of Information Act request and shared with The Republic.

The correspondence in these documents sheds some light on a process that is being repeated today with little transparency. Agency officials are being told to remain tight-lipped and to direct media queries to Customs and Border Protection. Despite persistent public records requests, local stakeholders, conservation groups and journalists receive little, if any, information on the plans and resource use happening with the ongoing construction.

The letters and assessments in the more than 260 pages of documents reviewed by The Republic paint a picture of agency personnel tasked with caring for these sensitive federally protected lands often scrambling to react to constantly changing construction plans, miscommunications and broken agreements with the Department of Homeland Security and its contractors. But as bad as the communication was then, it is worse this time around, officials and locals say.

“The DHS strategy of achieving more security along the international border exemplified a general lack of respect for the mission of the Service, and showed an almost total disregard for the principles of basic collaboration and honest communication which have greatly damaged working relationships and trust,” the Fish and Wildlife Service wrote in its 2008 Narrative Report.

The documents also illustrate a level of persistence required by Fish and Wildlife field staff to negotiate compromises in the face of “train wreck scale” proposals from the border security agency, as San Bernardino Refuge manager Bill Radke described initial plans in a 2008 email.

Those included building “pedestrian” fencing — bollard-style fencing — that would halt wildlife migration, building a base and surveillance towers as well as drilling wells on the refuge, and creating a road where there previously was nothing but impassable, steep and eroded terrain.

"An effective vehicle barrier already exists along much of the south refuge boundary, which has completely eliminated illegal vehicle incursions through the refuge," Radke wrote to a colleague in 2007. "Construction of a human impenetrable fence through a wetland would harm more habitat than it would ultimately protect."

In the end, the agencies and their partners, including the Malpai Group, managed to negotiate some wins: They prevented bollard-style fencing from being built through the San Pedro River. The Department of Homeland Security listened to the Fish and Wildlife Service’s suggestion of placing Normandy-style barriers in the river corridor and stationing agents there full time. The Border Patrol removes the barriers during the monsoon, and the Bureau of Land Management has stated the method is working.

"Currently, seasonal removal of the 'Normandy' style vehicular barriers has allowed the San Pedro River to maintain natural processes," the agency wrote in 2019 comments about the current construction proposal.

In the San Bernardino Refuge, Customs and Border Protection built a vehicle barrier along the refuge that was up to security standards, but also allowed wildlife to pass through. Though more water was pumped from the aquifer that supplies the San Bernardino Refuge than ever had been historically, no new wells were drilled. No camera towers or forward operating bases were built there as originally proposed. The agency's contractors took steps to mitigate flooding caused by some of the new barriers. They didn’t tear down the wildlife-friendly vehicle barrier that the refuge had built with its own funds two years before the new construction began.

In a 2007 email to a colleague, Radke described how the number of migrants detained on and adjacent to the refuge had decreased by more than 70 percent between 2002, before the vehicle barrier, and 2006, a year after the barrier was completed, attributing the change to the barrier and an increased law enforcement presence in the area.

“We continue to have a major problem along the border, but also have the ability to control that problem with an active and continuing law enforcement presence,” Radke wrote in that email. “If provided adequate support, we can provide protection to staff and visitors and protect cultural and natural resources on and adjacent to the refuges."

'No respect' for damage to lands

But more conflicts were lost. Where thick chaparral, mesquite and cottonwood trees had overtaken the Roosevelt easement, making it impossible for vehicles to drive there and difficult for humans to navigate, Customs and Border Protection built a wide all-weather road across nearly the entire San Bernardino Valley to the New Mexico state line.

In 2009, migrants were caught on camera crossing over the new vehicle barriers into the U.S. and using the road at the refuge boundary — an impact the Fish and Wildlife Service had anticipated.

On one part of the easement along the refuge’s boundary, instead of vehicle barriers that wildlife could pass through easily, the Department of Homeland Security's contractor built eight-strand barbed wire fencing. A deer attempted to jump the fence, got its hind leg caught in the wires, and died there. The contractor eventually replaced the fence with a wildlife-friendly vehicle barrier.

They bulldozed soil into a stream channel, leaving refuge staff scrambling to remove hundreds of endangered Yaqui topminnow from the stream in the midst of construction. The contractor cleared a 300-foot by 300-foot staging area on the refuge with no warning, and narrowly avoided one of the Slaughter Ranch’s historic building foundations.

“We are continually told one thing while they take action to do something else,” Radke angrily wrote in a 2008 email to colleagues, apparently having reached a limit, his writing style contrasting with his usual diplomatic tone.

“There appears to be no respect whatsoever regarding damage to refuge lands," he wrote. "Nobody made a simple phone call to the refuge to discuss this before they bulldozed. The contractor is blaming the Army Corps. Army Corps is remaining quiet. Border Patrol acts like they don’t know anything about the issue. Accountability and coordination regarding this border construction is absolutely sickening.”

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers oversaw the contractor on the project.

As construction was nearing its end in March 2010, Robert Krentz, a prominent rancher in the area and Malpai Group member, was killed on his ranch 20 miles north of the refuge. Authorities determined that the 58-year-old rancher was likely shot by drug smugglers. The community was shaken and the ranchers were angry. They felt their concerns had been ignored and now it was too late.

After Krentz’s murder, McDonald traveled to Washington, D.C., to testify before two House committees about border issues. He urged the government to increase the number of agents stationed in the area and invest in technology that would allow for better surveillance and communication in the remote area.

“It is our own government’s policy of forcing the illegal crossers into the most rural, most formidable terrain that is responsible for the traffic we are enduring,” he testified. “They are not deterred by high mountains, steep canyons, brush, or scarce water, and certainly not by high fences in the middle of nowhere.”

Customs and Border Protection listened.

They increased their agent presence in the region, built more vehicle barriers, and installed high-tech camera towers throughout the valley. The Malpai helped them identify a strategic location for a new forward operating base.

“The result of all that is we felt like we finally got to a good partnership with them,” McDonald said. And the combined strategies of camera towers, increased law enforcement and vehicle barriers seemed to work.

“There was no activity out here,” McDonald said. “(Border Patrol) were being very transparent about the fact that they weren’t catching anybody down here anymore, or catching very few, and that the integrated fixed towers were working very well.”

At the Slaughter Ranch, Border Patrol agents often stop to chat with the Dunns to pass the time, they said. “When Border Patrol starts referring to your area as Snoozeville, that kinda says something,” Fred said.

There's been a dramatic decline in cross-border activity in both Douglas and the areas surrounding it since the watchtowers were installed in 2016. The Cochise County Sheriff's Office currently has 700 additional cameras that monitor the area. "There's been a huge decrease (in traffic)," said Sheriff Mark Dannels in a phone interview. "I don't think we've had a drug load in the past 24 months."

The new construction, which began in late September, was a shock to many; McDonald said they didn't hear about the current wall construction until it hit the papers, and by then, it was too late to do anything.

"Malpai was built on trust," he said. "We worked really hard to establish trust between ranchers, environmental organizations, agency folks and everybody who cares about the area. We felt we had a good relationship with the Border Patrol here. It worked against us because we had too much confidence in the local leadership.

"I’m sure in Washington they looked down here and said here's a road running next to the border, here's Roosevelt easement, not a lot of private property concerns, let's put it there," he said. "Because they're trying to get up as much wall as they can as fast as they can. It's not a border security thing, it's a political thing.”

Trying to preserve a rugged country

In the San Bernardino Valley, when night falls, the earth is swallowed up, and the stars freckle the sky. The only lights are the distant stream of traffic on Highway 2 in Mexico to the south and the glow of Douglas to the west. The huge sky with its infinite speckles of light imbues a sense of smallness, a feeling of the Earth’s fragility.

Conserving an unfragmented landscape was one of the original goals of the Malpai Group, and it remains the core of its mission. They have protected some 80,000 acres of private land from development so far, and in doing so, helped protect the public lands throughout it. The openness of this place is why McDonald loves it, despite the difficulties of living in such a remote place.

“It’s a tough life in many ways,” McDonald said. “Isolated compared to many people, though not as much as it used to be and there are things that you give up by living out here. But one of the great amenities of it is the beauty of the area and the wildlife. And those things are being compromised by the wall.”

The new border wall system, including the 19 miles in the San Bernardino Valley, will include lighting, Customs and Border Protection said, though the agency wouldn’t confirm whether the lights would be on throughout the night because the information is law enforcement-sensitive.

“When you left Douglas, you used to look out there and it was open space,” McDonald said. “Of course, there’s some stuff going on in Mexico on the other side and you'll see a few lights where you never saw them before and that may increase over time, I don't know. But the fact of the matter is this shatters the whole open space thing and that hurts.”

Places like the San Pedro River and the San Bernardino Valley and the limited water that makes these areas habitable will face continuing threats from climate change and groundwater use in the area. The border wall, critics say, will unnecessarily add to existing stresses. Amid the many concerns, construction continues quickly in the San Bernardino Valley; about 6 miles of noncontiguous fencing has been completed in the area on either side of the refuge. Construction appears imminent at the San Pedro.

For people like McDonald, the frustration is in the fact that those who will live with the wall are essentially powerless to stop it, or at the least have a way to make their two cents heard.

“I wish we had the opportunity to talk about this before it was being built. Maybe one day they'll tear the damn thing down or at least not put on the lights,” McDonald said, a weariness in his voice. “There are a lot of beautiful places in this country, but they won't stay beautiful if we don’t try to take care of them.”

(CNN) This weekend will be a glimpse of the long, hot summer ahead for many Americans. A " dangerous and deadly heat wave " is on track to bake several southwestern states over the next few days, the National Weather Service warns. 1. January 6

The House select committee investigating the US Capitol insurrection on January 6, 2021, will hold its first prime-time televised hearing today at 8 p.m. ET. The committee's central mission has been to uncover the full scope of former President Donald Trump's unprecedented attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election and stop the transfer of power to President Joe Biden. These highly choreographed hearings will be the panel's first opportunity to show the public what it's learned from more than 1,000 witness interviews and 135,000 documents during its 10-month investigation. Today's hearing will also shine a spotlight on the nine-member committee , which features seven Democrats and two Republicans, and set the stage for subsequent hearings in the coming days.

2. Gun violence

Victims of the Uvalde elementary school massacre and other recent mass shootings gave first-hand descriptions of the horrors of gun violence at a House committee meeting on Wednesday. In a pre-recorded video, 11-year-old Miah Cerrillo, a fourth-grade student at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde , described trying to hide behind her teacher's desk and covering herself in blood in an attempt to survive. It marked a rare moment for Congress to hear testimony from someone as young as Cerrillo on a subject as sensitive and disturbing as gun violence. Family members of shooting victims also made passionate pleas for gun legislation. The hearing, however, clearly displayed the partisan divide in the debate on guns as Democrats urged stronger gun control, while Republicans pushed back on restrictions.

"The Russians are destroying everything," Serhiy Hayday, head of the Luhansk regional military administration, said in a televised announcement Wednesday, "They are firing tanks and artillery at residential buildings," he added. Separately, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that " millions of people may starve " if Russia continues its blockade of Ukraine's ports. The UN secretary-general made similar remarks Wednesday , saying the war threatens to "unleash an unprecedented wave of hunger and destitution" around the world.

The House of Representatives yesterday passed a roughly $40 billion bill to deliver aid to Ukraine as it continues to face Russia's brutal assault. The measure will next need to be passed by the Senate before it can go to President Joe Biden to be signed into law. According to the measure, billions of dollars will be used to send military equipment and weapons from US stocks to Ukraine and to purchase weapons from contractors, among several other allocations. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky thanked House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the "friends" of his country for approving the bill. This comes as Belarus, an ally of Russia, said it will deploy special forces to the border of Ukraine because "the United States and its allies continue to increase their military presence at the state borders," a military official said.

West Virginia and Nebraska held primary elections yesterday , and former President Donald Trump suffered his first big loss of 2022 in Nebraska after his chosen candidate for governor in the Republican primary lost to the state party's choice. Trump fared better in West Virginia, where his pick in a hotly contested GOP House primary cruised to victory in a battle of Republican incumbents. The first few rounds of 2022 primaries have doubled as a proving ground for Trump's ability to bend the Republican Party to his will. That theme will continue into next week's slate, especially in Pennsylvania, where his endorsed Senate candidate is heading into a three-way race for the GOP nomination.

(You can get "5 Things You Need to Know Today" delivered to your inbox daily. Sign up here .)

1. Ukraine

2. Abortion

3. Gas prices

President Joe Biden is considering releasing about 1 million barrels of oil per day from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to alleviate persistent high gas prices . Tapping the stockpile of 600 million barrels of crude oil, which are stored in underground salt caverns in Louisiana and Texas, probably won't have a huge effect on gas prices because of limits on how much oil can be released at a time. But it's a political sign from Biden that he is trying to address the problem. The US price of a gallon of regular gasoline spiked after Russia invaded Ukraine, hitting a record high of $4.33 earlier this month. The invasion has also snarled global supply chains that were supposed to be recovering from pandemic-related woes.

JUST WATCHED Return to work burdens Americans amid high gas prices Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Return to work burdens Americans amid high gas prices 01:40

4. Immigration

The Biden administration is planning to end controversial Trump-era pandemic restrictions on the US-Mexico border by May 23. The public health provision, known as Title 42, has largely blocked migrants from entering the US and has attracted the consternation of Democrats and immigration advocates who say there is no scientific justification for the restriction. Nonetheless, the Biden administration has kept the measure in place. (CNN) A 17-year-old has become the youngest person to fly around the world solo in a small aircraft on Wednesday after first taking off on March 23, according to Guinness World Records (GWR).

British-Belgian national Mack Rutherford touched down earlier in the day in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia, where his journey began, according to Rutherford's official website and GWR. He first set off when he was still 16.

Rutherford's route spanned 52 countries across five continents on a specially prepared ultralight Shark aircraft with cruising speed reaching 300 km/h, according to his website.

"I want to use the opportunity to meet young people on my route who do incredible things, making a difference to their communities or even to the world," he wrote before jetting off.

His journey was tracked on his website, which shows he set off from Bulgaria towards the Mediterranean then through the Sahara, onwards through the Middle East and then East Asia.

search_result.text:
Mark Carlson

Associated Press

CHARLEROI, Belgium – A Belgian British teenage pilot was on track Tuesday to become the youngest person to fly around the world solo in a small plane as he landed in southern Belgium ahead of the penultimate leg of his global odyssey.

Mack Rutherford, who turned 17 during the journey, touched down at Buzet Airstrip near the city of Charleroi, where he originally learned to fly. He’s due to land in Bulgaria on Wednesday.

His aim: to displace Travis Ludlow of Britain, who was 18 when he set the record in 2021.

Rutherford is flying a Shark, one of the fastest ultralight aircraft in the world with a cruising speed reaching 186 mph, which has been specially fitted out for the long journey. It’s normally a two-seater, but an extra fuel tank has been installed next to the young pilot.

Another record breaker:She's 19 years old. And she just became the youngest woman to fly solo around the world.

It’s the same kind of aircraft used by his 19-year-old sister, Zara Rutherford, when she set the world record on Jan. 20 for the youngest woman to fly solo around the world.

Mack’s lonely journey, which began on March 23, took him through 52 countries over five continents. To conform with Guinness World Records requirements, the route crossed the equator twice.

“It was supposed to take between two to three months and it’s been five months now,” he told The Associated Press. Administrative formalities in Crete and Dubai “because of paperwork issues, visas, permits, things like that,” caused the delay.

Gen Z drivers:The kids are all fight: How millennials, Gen Z are driving change on climate

The flight took him through Africa and the Gulf region – where he face periods of extreme heat –— then on to India, China, South Korea and Japan. From there, he headed to Alaska and down the U.S. West Coast to Mexico. The teen then headed north again along the U.S. East Coast to Canada, across the Atlantic via Iceland, to the U.K. and Belgium.

If all goes well, and weather permitting, he’ll fly east across Europe via Slovakia and land at an airport in the Bulgarian capital, Sofia, on Wednesday.

Proud father Sam Rutherford said his two children have set a shining example.

“They have got around the world safely, effectively, professionally. And they’ve shown to other youngsters that you don’t have to be 18 even, and certainly not 30, to make a difference and do something and follow your dreams,” he told AP.

search_result.title: A 19-year-old is trying to become the youngest woman to fly around ...
search_result.text:
Nineteen-year-old Zara Rutherford was born to fly.

The Belgian-British teen is the daughter of two pilots, so when she announced she wanted to fly a tiny two-seat plane around the world alone, her parents were fully on board.

"I always thought it would be too unrealistic – it was impossible. It was complex, it was expensive," she told USA TODAY. "Then I figured … wouldn't it be better to start when I'm younger than rather than older, because then you get caught up in life and careers and jobs, and I didn't know if I would ever have an opportunity like this? I told my dad, 'This is an idea I have, and what do you think?' Straightaway, he says: 'Yes, we will find sponsorship. We'll make it work.'"

They did make it work, because Rutherford is in the midst of her solo flight across the globe, and if she completes it, she will be the youngest woman ever to do so. The record is now held by Shaesta Waiz, who flew around the globe solo when she was 30 years old.

►Hurricane Ida:Storm forecast to reach Category 4 strength as Louisiana coast braces for direct hit

►Afghanistan:A timeline of the US withdrawal and Taliban recapture of country

Waiz, who originally connected with Rutherford via a LinkedIn message, said she encouraged the young pilot to take down the record.

"I remember thinking: 'I cannot be the youngest woman. I'm not that young,'" Waiz told USA TODAY. "Here comes Zara, and she's just so ambitious and very smart. She reached out to me … to say that she was going to do this. The first thing she asked me, she said, 'Is it OK if I break your record?' I was like: 'Absolutely Zara. Records are meant to be broken.'"

Rutherford's route began in her home nation, Belgium. She took off from an airport in Brussels on Aug. 11 and has since made stops in the United Kingdom, Iceland, Greenland and Canada. She is now in New York City, where she has two rest days, and her next stop is North Carolina, where she will visit the Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kitty Hawk.

The teen aviator flies about five hours nearly every day; the longest solo flight she had ever done before her world record attempt was about 4½ hours. Rutherford said she avoids eating or drinking much before she boards her plane so she doesn't need to use the bathroom while she is in the air.

"I say that, but on my flight from (Goose Bay, Canada) to Montreal, I had to make an emergency stop," she said with a laugh.

The long hours in the plane can get lonely; Rutherford said she mostly listens to podcasts to pass the time. She said her favorite is 20-year-old YouTuber Emma Chamberlain's podcast "Anything Goes."

"Especially like over Greenland, you lose radio almost immediately, so it's really quiet, she said. "If you get a podcast that's just one person talking, then it feels like there's someone there with you."

Rutherford said her favorite stop has been Kulusuk, Greenland, because of the scenic landscape.

"I saw my very first whale, so that was amazing, and it's such a stunning sight," she said. "You know the wallpapers that come with a computer of like beautiful scenery? If you take your phone out and snap literally any picture, it looks like that."

For Guinness World Records to consider the trip truly "around the world," Rutherford has to cross points on opposite sides of the globe. On her route, those spots are just below the equator in Columbia and just above the equator in Indonesia. She added nearly 5,000 miles to the trip so she would be able to visit more places.

Waiz said that while she did not directly help Rutherford plan her route, she did offer advice about weather and other challenges she might face during the journey.

"The weather can really turn on you at any time, so you really have to be just aware of what to expect in different parts of the world during the season," she said. "I told her: 'Only you know if you should take off. Try not to let anything pressure you or commitments you've made around the world. People can wait. At the end of the day, it's you in that plane, so do whatever is best for you.'"

Rutherford said her flights have been mostly smooth sailing, but she did have one stressful moment on her flight from Iceland to Greenland. Her plane cannot fly through clouds, and she hit an overcast system where the clouds forced her to drop to 600 feet. She said she considered turning back, but the clouds cleared up and she was able to continue to her next stop.

Waiz believes Rutherford's humility and intelligence give her a good chance to succeed.

"If you have an ego going into it, it can really hurt you, so I think Zara being very humble is definitely going to help," she said. "You just never know what Mother Nature's going to do. I feel like she's a pretty grounded person, and she has a really great intuition."

Waiz is founder and president of a nonprofit called Dreams Soar, which educates girls around the world about aviation. Dreams Soar is one of Rutherford's charity partners on her flight, and the teen will meet up with Waiz and local Women of Aviation chapter on her stop in Jacksonville, Florida.

Rutherford is projected to complete her trip on Nov. 3, and though she said the three months remaining are daunting, she is taking things one day at a time.

"It sounds like a lifetime, but actually, I'm really enjoying it. I rarely think about it as a whole. It's always one flying leg at a time. That way you kind of forget about the bigger picture."

Contact Emily Adams at eaadams@gannett.com or on Twitter @eaadams6.

search_result.title: Pilot sets record for youngest woman to fly solo around the world
search_result.text:
Marta Fiorin and Raf Casert

Associated Press

KORTRIJK, Belgium — The 19-year-old Belgian-British pilot Zara Rutherford set a world record as the youngest woman to fly solo around the world, touching her small airplane down in western Belgium on Thursday — 155 days after she departed.

Rutherford will find herself in the Guinness World Records book after setting the mark that had been held by 30-year-old American aviator Shaesta Waiz since 2017.

The overall record will remain out of Rutherford’s grasp, since Briton Travis Ludlow set that benchmark last year as an 18-year-old.

Her global flight in her ultralight Shark plane was supposed to take three months, but relentless bad weather and visa issues kept her grounded sometimes for weeks on end, extending her adventure by about two months.

Zara Rutherford on her historic flight:'I always thought it would be too unrealistic' but 'wouldn't it be better to start when I'm younger?'

On Thursday, rain, drizzle, sunshine and even a rainbow over Kortrijk airport exemplified the changing, often bad weather she had been facing all too often.

After she was escorted by a four-plane formation in a huge V across much of Belgium, she did a flyby of the airport before finally landing. After waving to the jubilant crowds, she embraced her parents and draped herself both in the Union Jack and Belgian tricolor flag.

“Winter in Europe poses a lot of challenges,” she said as she was held back for days on the last few legs of the trip. Then again, she had had to deal with -31 F in Siberia and 90 F in Indonesia. Fog, smoke from wildfires and even typhoons also held her back.

In her trek of more than 28,000 nautical miles, she stopped over in five continents and visited 41 nations.

“The people were incredible, everywhere," she said.

Rutherford’s flight saw her steer clear of wildfires in California, deal with biting cold over Russia and narrowly avoid North Korean airspace. She flew by Visual Flight Rules, basically going on sight only, often slowing down progress when more sophisticated systems could have led her through clouds and fog.

Sometimes she feared for her life, and at other times she simply yearned for the simple comforts of home. Flying runs in her blood since both her parents are pilots and she has been traveling in small planes since she was 6. At 14, she started flying herself.

With the final touchdown, the teenager wants to infuse young women and girls worldwide with the spirit of aviation — and an enthusiasm for studies in the exact sciences, mathematics, engineering and technology.

Individuals who make less than $125,000 a year but did not receive Pell Grants are eligible for $10,000 in loan forgiveness. So, what steps do eligible borrowers need to take ? 2. Kobe Bryant

A federal jury awarded $31 million in damages after finding the Los Angeles County Sheriff and Fire departments liable for infringing on the constitutional rights of Vanessa Bryant and co-plaintiff Christopher Chester, who each lost a spouse and daughter in the helicopter crash in January 2020 .
